ping

This is weird... for this NPE to happen, either InternalPlatform.getDefault() or
InternalPlatform.getRuntimeFileManager() should have returned null. The first is
impossible (is statically initialized). The second is possible, but should have
caused a log entry to be created.

Grant, I guess you may want to try running with -Declipse.noRegistryCache=true
(I know, I know...). That would skip the code that is failing for you know, and
may allow you to run.

FWIW, adding this switch gets me as far as the "choose a workspace" dialog, but 
then it always says "workspace in use, choose a different one", even if I 
specify a directory that does not exist.  It seems to create the .lock file in 
the new workspace and then check for it and think that it's already in use (?).
Grant, just to confirm: is this with today's build (08:16AM)?
yes

On HP you may have to specify -Dosgi.locking=java.io as a vm arg on the command 
line or as a property setting in the config.ini

Oh, boy... the entry for the IOException while retrieving the File Manager *is*
there (I missed it)...

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime May 18, 2004 11:29:31.425
!MESSAGE Exception trying to create the fileManager for the 
area: "/bluebird/teamswt/ggayed/hpux30M9/eclipse/configuration//org.eclipse.core
.runtime".

Unfortunately we are eating the IOException and not including it in the log, so
it is hard to say what is going on.

Created an attachment (id=10796)
patched runtime.jar

Grant, could you please replace
eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.0.0/runtime.jar with this one and
try again?
Alternatively, you can try with the 4PM build (the same change went in).

Created an attachment (id=10800)
exceptions I get with the new jar

I tried substituting the new jar in, but now I get a new set of exceptions on
startup (they are attached).  The top one seems to indicate that the zip can't
be read, but the root exception is farther down, so I'm not sure what the real
cause is.  I did chmod the jar's permissions to 777.

Created an attachment (id=10867)
trace with 0519 integration build

(sorry for the late follow-up, I've been testing on other platforms today)

I took the latest integration build and it still doesn't start.  My
command-line, so that you can verify my osgi.locking value, is:

./eclipse -vm /opt/java1.4/jre/bin/java -vmargs -Dosgi.locking=java.io -Xmx256M
-XdoCloseWithReadPending &

I also tried -Dosgi.locking=none

The trace that it writes (with -Dosgi.locking=java.io) is attached.

It was expected to fail, since the change was only to produce more information
on the error.

What is weird is that we still try to lock the file even if other options are
explicitly passed in the command line. Maybe we are not getting the properties
properly?

Any comments, Pascal?

This actually also happens on Windows... a java.nio lock will be tried no matter
what the value for osgi.locking property is. It seems the call responsible for
initializing the locker that knows about the property is being executed *after*
other calls that don't specify any locking mode (getting the default) are executed.
Fixed in HEAD.

Should this fix be in the 200405200800 integration build?  It's still not 
starting for me.

Yes, normally you should be able to start specifying -Dosgi.locking=none or 
java.io
Let me know if you want to visit and see the failure on our hpux.
Investigating...

Thanx for fixing this Rafael.
I verified and tested for 4pm build.
